awd_titl_txt: Investigating Fundamental Chemical and Physical Processes Affecting Gas-Particle Partitioning Using Levitated Droplet-Mass Spectrometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry. Professor Frank Keutsch of Harvard University and his students investigate the fundamental processes involved in separating compounds between the air and the surface of particles (aerosols) in the atmosphere. This portioning between the air and the surfaces of solids that are present in the air is poorly understood however, one phase may be preferred over the other due to incomplete mixing, physical barriers, and/or chemical reactions on the aerosol particles. Laboratory studies are conducted on single aerosol particles to isolate and investigate how and why compounds stick to their surfaces. These experimental studies provide fundamental parameters for improving computer models on aerosol formation and changes in these particles with time (ageing). This research is important as it may ultimately improve regional and global models of aerosols, which are relevant to air quality and human and animal health. Professor Keutsch also designs laboratory experiments to introduce a systems approach to undergraduate education.  This approach considers not only individual reactions but the coupled chemical and physical feedbacks that exist between different parts of the whole system (in this case, the gas and solid phases). His students learn about instrumentation design and reactions at and far from equilibrium. In addition, underrepresented high school students at Cambridge, MA high schools are mentored and work in the research laboratory learning to communicate their research to others in the field and gaining confidence in their abilities to participate in scientific fields. 

A new approach is used to study aerosol partitioning that combines levitation of individual micron-sized particles with mass-spectrometric (MS) detection. This technique allows the measurement of the molecular-level evolution of a droplet over atmospherically relevant time scales. Molecular-level detection is a novel approach that may advances trapped droplet methods. After further optimization of the trapped-droplet MS, specific research questions related to the role of non-ideal mixing, oligomer formation, transition metal complex photochemistry, and aerosol physical properties in gas-particle partitioning are addressed. This research is done in collaboration with chemists and atmospheric sciences. Results are compared with state-of-the-art models which improve the representation of the fundamental chemical and physical processes in the models, and hence, improve predictive capabilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Aerosols are tiny particles suspended in the atmosphere with significant impacts on both climate and health. They interact with solar radiation and influence cloud formation, affecting Earth’s radiative balance. Unlike greenhouse gases, which mix fairly evenly in the atmosphere, aerosols exhibit complex, region-specific behaviors that contribute to climate forcing but are harder to quantify precisely due to their variability and complex composition. This complexity makes it challenging to predict their full climate impact accurately, and brown carbon, i.e., aerosol consisting of brown colored organic compounds is a prime example for this. Furthermore, aerosols can contain organic and inorganic compounds that, upon inhalation, affect human health by exacerbating respiratory and cardiovascular diseases. 

One of the primary challenges in aerosol research is faithfully recreating ambient atmospheric conditions in the laboratory. Laboratory studies aim to mimic real-world scenarios, but achieving the same concentrations and timescales observed in nature is often difficult. Techniques like bulk solution studies offer control but lack certain features of atmospheric aerosols, such as surface-to-volume ratios and particle-phase interactions, i.e., the evaporation of compounds to the atmosphere is not as important as in the real environment. In addition, most laboratory studies with particles suffer from the limited lifetime of particles even in larger chambers due to loss via collision with walls, while in the atmosphere they can survive for weeks to months. Single-particle levitation methods, such as Electrodynamic Balance-Mass Spectrometry (EDB-MS), have emerged as a novel approach to address these limitations. By levitating individual aerosol particles in a controlled gas stream, researchers can observe their interactions over timescales relevant to atmospheric conditions. This setup allows for more accurate simulations of aerosol lifetimes and behavior, especially in studying the competition between processes like gas-particle partitioning and chemical reactions within individual particles. Some example systems that were investigated with this approach under this grant are:

Butenedial-Ammonia Reactions:

Studies have shown that butenedial, a dialdehyde common in polluted urban environments, can react with ammonia to form brown carbon—particles that absorb sunlight and contribute to warming. In these reactions, butenedial forms nitrogen-containing compounds and accretes into larger molecules. However, unlike similar compounds like glyoxal, butenedial does not produce significant oligomeric structures and reacts relatively quickly with ammonia. In single-particle studies, the butenedial-ammonia reaction displayed variability based on humidity levels, highlighting that this reaction's rate can significantly impact brown carbon formation and aerosol loading in certain atmospheric conditions. Brown carbon plays an important role as it is a light absorbing aerosol with impacts on climate and our study shows that under most atmospheric conditions butenedial will evaporate to the gas-phase but in regions with high ammonia concentrations formation of brown carbon is competitive, representing a distinct regional effect on brown carbon formation.

Glyoxal Reactions

Glyoxal, an atmospherically abundant dialdehyde, behaves differently in the atmosphere. It tends to form hydrates and larger structures in aqueous environments, especially in the presence of salts. Studies using glyoxal as a model compound have found that it has a strong salting-in effect with sulfate, increasing its atmospheric lifetime and promoting particle-phase reactions. This behavior, which is distinct from butenedial’s, underscores the diversity within dicarbonyl reactions and indicates that environmental factors such as ion presence and humidity significantly affect aerosol chemistry. 

Iron Complexes in Aerosols

The iron(III) complexes, particularly those with malonic and oxalic acids, are interesting in aerosol aging and oxidation processes. Under humid conditions, these complexes photodegrade faster, as water facilitates the diffusion of reactive oxygen species (ROS) into particle interiors, accelerating degradation. In contrast, dry conditions limit ROS diffusion, slowing oxidation. Experiments comparing single particles to bulk solutions have shown that the photochemical degradation of iron-oxalate is faster than that of iron-malonate in both systems, although the reaction kinetics in bulk solutions tend to be faster due to shorter diffusion paths. These findings are essential for understanding the oxidation mechanisms within aerosols and highlight the influence of environmental factors like humidity on aerosol transformation and the lifetime of organic aerosol.

Conclusion

Our studies demonstrate the complexity of atmospheric aerosol influenced by complex internal chemistries and interactions with environmental variables like humidity and salt content. Innovations in single-particle levitation techniques have advanced our ability to replicate and study atmospheric particle behaviors more accurately. The findings on butenedial-ammonia reactions, glyoxal's interaction with salts, and the photochemical properties of iron complexes underscore the diversity of aerosol chemistry and its dependence on ambient conditions, explaining regional difference, e.g., in brown carbon that have been observed.
